contactMessage: For information about this page please contact

portalBuilder.editSelectPage: Select the page you want to edit
portalBuilder.editDefaultOrderHeader: Edit the current custom page order
portalBuilder.createDefaultOrderHeader: Create a new custom page order
portalBuilder.enterPageName: Enter a name for the portal page
portalBuilder.enterPageShorthand: Enter a shorthand for the portal page (letters only)
portalBuilder.enterPageVisible: Select if the page should be visible
portalBuilder.enterPageShowName: Select if the page name should be shown
portalBuilder.enterPageNumCols: Enter the number of columns on the page
portalBuilder.pageAlreadyExistsAlert: Error: A page with this name alreay exists. Page names must be unique!
portalBuilder.invalidShorthand: Please enter a shorthand name - no blanks and unique per Portal
portalBuilder.editSelectObject: Select the object you want to edit
portalBuilder.enterObjectName: Enter a name for the object
portalBuilder.enterObjectID: Enter an ID for the object - no blanks and unique per page
portalBuilder.selectObjectWidthDropdownText: Select the width of the object:
selectObjectWidth: Auto - let object grow as big as needed by its content
0 - make the object take up a whole row
1 - make the object take up 75% of the row
2 - make the object take up 66% of the row
3 - make the object take up 50% of the row
4 - make the object take up 33% of the row
5 - make the object take up 25% of the row
portalBuilder.enterObjectHeight: Optional - Enter the height of the object, if left blank the content will get as much content as needed - enter both a value and the unit, i.e. 100vh
portalBuilder.objectBorderLabel: Do you want a boarder around the object?
portalBuilder.enterObjectTextContent: Specify the text content of the object here - for text styling please see documentation on Text Rendering:
linkListTabBehavior: Tab - opens the link in a new browser tab
Same - opens the link in the current window
portalBuilder.linkListText: For each link you have to provide a display text (what the user will see) and the link
portalBuilder.viyaCheckboxLabel: Link is to SAS Viya content - if so exclude the base URL from the link and start with the /
portalBuilder.icHeightPlaceholder: Special cases - specify a height including a unit (e.g. 700px)
portalBuilder.icWidthPlaceholder: Special cases - specify a width including a unit (e.g. 700px)
portalBuilder.vaReportURIPlaceholder: Enter the URI of your report - e.g. /reports/reports/UUID
portalBuilder.vaReportPartPlaceholder: Here you can specify a page- or object-ID, instead of displaying the full report
portalBuilder.noFurtherConfigurationText: There are no further configuration options for this object type
portalBuilder.runCustomCodeComputeContextPlaceholder: Please enter the exact compute context name, e.g. SAS Studio compute context
portalBuilder.runCustomCodeCodeExplainer: Check this link for more information on how to enter code here
portalBuilder.runCustomCodeActionExplainer: The choosen action will be applied to a specified report object
portalBuilder.runCustomCodeActionElementPlaceholder: ID of the report object, e.g. pageShorthand-obj-objectID
portalBuilder.runCustomCodeUnloadCodePlaceholder: The syntax is similiar to the previous way code was entered
portalBuilder.dateProductSchemaURIExplainer: Find the documentation on how to create a data product schema here
portalBuilder.dataProductSchemaURI: URI of the data product schema /files/files/UUID
portalBuilder.dataProductFolderURI: URI of the data product folder for which the user of this page require write access /folders/folders/UUID
portalBuilder.copyContentExplainer: Add URIs of content that should be copied over - /reports/reports and /files/files are supported
portalBuilder.dataProductOwnerFolderURI: Enter the folder where the product purchases are stored
portalBuilder.dataProductHeaderAttributesPlaceholder: Enter the attributes you want in the data like this: ['dataType', 'sensitivityLevel']

masScore.scoreImportHeader: Please select a file with the same structure as the module inputs - without headers
masScore.successfullModuleDeletion: The MAS Module was deleted successfully.
masScore.failedModuleDeletion: Unable to delete the MAS Module. Please check the developer console or contact your SAS Administrator.

oauthClientActionText.text: Update the secret of a client

clienAdministrator.oauthClientExplainer:
In the client list there are also many sas.* clients, these are used by SAS Viya itself and should not be changed.
For more information about the different client attributes please read the SAS documentation.
clienAdministrator.oauthClientAuthenticatorText1: For editing/creating the OAuth clients a special token must be generated, click on the following link:
clienAdministrator.oauthClientAuthenticatorText2: , assume the administrative group and copy the full URL value into the input field:
clienAdministrator.oauthClientNoTokenError: Please enter an authentication token as described above.

scrScore.endpoint: Please enter the SCR endpoint (click outside of the field to trigger metadata fetching):

promptBuilder.promptBuilderDescription: Craft precise and effective prompts for language models. Select from various models and customize their options to optimize performance and achieve the desired outputs. Get started by selecting a model, adjusting the parameters, and entering your prompts.
promptBuilder.promptBuilderProjectHeader: Select or Create a Project that is used for the Prompt Tracking

promptBuilderCreatePrompt.modalTitle: Create a new Prompt - The new Prompt will be saved into the currently selected project

promptBuilder.promptBuilderModelSelectorHeading: Select the LLMs to test Prompts with
promptBuilder.promptBuilderPromptingHeader: Start building and testing your prompt
promptBuilder.promptBulderPromptingExplainer:
The left input field is for the system prompt, here you should enter how the LLM should behave/act/respond and give it a more or less static task description. The right input field is for the user prompt, which is the variable part the system prompt should be applied to.
In the user prompt input field you can structure your inputs in the following fashion to introduce a variable input schema that will than also be turned into the documented inputs of the prompt for further use - variable names can not contain spaces and as semicolons are reserved as a separator:
variableName1:variableValue;variableName2:variableValue;....
promptBuilder.promptBuilderTemperatureInfo:
Temperature is a parameter that controls the randomness or creativity of the model's responses. It adjusts how the model generates text by affecting the probability distribution of the next word or token in the sequence.
Low Temperature (e.g., 0.1 - 0.5): Responses are more deterministic and focused
Medium Temperature (e.g., 0.5 - 1.0): Balances between creativity and predictability
High Temperature (e.g., 1.0 - 2.0): Responses are more diverse and less predictable
promptBuilder.promptBuilderTop_PInfo:
Top-p (also known as nucleus sampling) is a parameter that controls the randomness and creativity of the model's responses by restricting the choice of possible next words or tokens. It influences how the model selects the next word by limiting the probability distribution to a specific subset of words.
Low Top-p (e.g., 0.1 - 0.3): The selection is more restricted and focused. Only the most probable words are considered, leading to more deterministic and focused responses
Medium Top-p (e.g., 0.4 - 0.7): Provides a balanced mix of creativity and predictability. The range of considered words is broader, allowing the model to include both common and less likely words
High Top-p (e.g., 0.8 - 1.0): The selection is broader and less restricted. The model considers a wider range of words, resulting in more creative and less predictable responses
promptBuilder.promptBuilderTop_KInfo: The Top-k parameter changes how the model selects tokens for output. A Top-k of 1 means the selected token is the most probable among all the tokens in the model's vocabulary (also called greedy decoding), while a topK of 3 means that the next token is selected from among the 3 most probable using the temperature. For each token selection step, the topK tokens with the highest probabilities are sampled. Tokens are then further filtered based on Top-p  with the final token selected using temperature sampling.
promptBuilder.promptBuilderMax_LengthInfo: Max_length: This parameter defines the upper boundary for the length of the generated text. Once the model reaches this token limit, it will stop generating further text, even if the completion is not fully finished.
promptBuilder.promptExperimentSelectModelsAlert: You have to select at least one LLM to run an experiment
promptBuilder.promptExperimentSaveModelsExperimentAler: You have to run at least one experiment
promptBuilder.promptExperimentSaveSucessResponse: The experiment has been saved. Here is a link to the prompt:
promptBuilder.promptExperimentSaveFailureResponse: The experiment couldn't be saved. Please ensure that you have write access to the prompt model in SAS Model Manager.
promptBuilder.promptBuilderModelCallFailed: The model call couldn't be generated please check with the Administrator.
promptBuilder.promptBuilderModelInferenceFailed: The model call failed, please check with the Administrator.
promptBuilder.promptBuilderCreateModelNoBestPrompt: You have to select a Best Prompt using the checkboxes.
promptBuilder.promptBuilderFastestPrompt: This model had the fastest response time in this experiment run
promptBuilder.promptBuilderFewestTokensPrompt: This model had the fewest output tokens in this experiment run
promptBuilder.promptBuilderBestPrompt: This response was selected as the best in this experiment run
